column5: I have never used any crayfish imitation baits.
i like the gary yamamoto flappin hogs. i usually use natural colours. greens, browns, blacks  the legs are fragile though. they only last maybe 2 or 3 fish
Reaction Innovations - Kinky Beaver or Sweet Beaver. Any combination of black, blue or red works great. Pumpkinseed or greens in clear water.
singingdog knows what up.

I'm old school I guess, my go to is always an uncle josh pork frog, mostly the crawfrog and phantom craw but have a handful of different cuts  I play around whatever fancy plastic craw looks cool at the store, but not brand loyal to anything specific except my uncle josh frogs

This is kinda a funny story but when I was a kid and a fish or rock or heavy pile of weeds would break my line and I'd loose my crayfish coloured Big O I would cry because it meant I had to use some orher terrible lure until I could buy a new one.

Big O's are an amazing lure.  Funny you should mention it, I got my first big O off of a snag when I was wading a river for smallmouth when I was 14 or 15, It was a chartreuse big O, and I still have that lure today.  It is one that has never been sacrificed to the fish gods (by me anyway).  I now have a box full of them!  They are probably my number 1 bass crank, and I have inadvertently landed many pickerel, musky, crappie etc. on them as well!

http://www.anglerschoice.ca/  Also, check out there Wart Hawgs in 6" size if you like fishing wacky. Unbelievable bait for me. My new favourite plastic. That picture on the site with the quick review is me on Simcoe. Highly recommend them and they are SO much durable than the senkos!

At my parents cottage it is only about 15 feet deep at the deepest and packed with Milfoil thick enough to stand on. The depth the Big O runs is perfect to keep the lure right in the strike zone. Beginning of the year too, when the milfoil is still growing, it skims right over the top without getting hung up.
On the big O, any other colors than craw work well for you guys, Never used them before, I may have to go pick up a few... and by a few......
Big O's don't work....you have to spend $25 on a hand-painted Japanese crankbait to catch bass.
Big O's don't work....you have to spend $25 on a hand-painted Japanese crankbait to catch bass. :clapping:
Big O's don't work....you have to spend $25 on a hand-painted Japanese crankbait to catch bass. That's what I've been doing wrong. I tried trolling with a $20 bill, caught nothing.. hahaha

Ill one up you with a hand painted big o hahaha. I dipped one in this glow in the dark chart. Stuff from the kids painting area from wal mart, the. Clear coated it. It was deadly. Guess i should make a few more...

I have never used any crayfish imitation baits.  Is that because you live in real province where you can still use REAL LIVE ones?  I quit bass fishing when they banned transporting crayfish over land in Ontario. Honestly I miss catching the crayfish more than the bass. Catching the crayfish took skill the bass not at all, once you knew the trick for the quarry I used to fish LOL.
The Yum F2 money craw in crawdad has been a workhorse for me. Although they don't look all that special they have great movement when falling.

i like the gary yamamoto flappin hogs. i usually use natural colours. greens, browns, blacks  the legs are fragile though. they only last maybe 2 or 3 fish      This is my go to  I fish mine Split shot rigged  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0FCRQlbB85k&list=UUE7AzcjFOafmhcoHRaWBtmA&feature=c4-overview   That's a flappin hogg hanging out of that fishes mouth as well as this creek fishes
Big O's don't work....you have to spend $25 on a hand-painted Japanese crankbait to catch bass. :ninja:
Chartreuse.  I own Big O's in most sizes and colors, but the chartreuse is the number one producer for me.  All of them are decent though, the fish just love that tight little wiggle!

Chartreuse. I own Big O's in most sizes and colors, but the chartreuse is the number one producer for me. All of them are decent though, the fish just love that tight little wiggle! White ones are actually deadly for lake specks

I think what this thread has shown is that a lot of quality fishermen use a lot of different lures to catch the same fish.  Sale hunt, try different profiles/rigs/colours and you'll find what works where & when.  It's more about how you fish the bait.  Most people new to soft plastics fish them way too fast or pop them way too much.

I think what this thread has shown is that a lot of quality fishermen use a lot of different lures to catch the same fish.  Sale hunt, try different profiles/rigs/colours and you'll find what works where & when.  It's more about how you fish the bait. Most people new to soft plastics fish them way too fast or pop them way too much.  Pretty spot on. I have been using soft plastics forever, just haven't really had early success craw ones, so I focused on what produced, but go curious.  Fishing for me is great because it is always changing, things aren't set in stone.  You guys are awesome, and the variety shown in terms of what people prefer is really eye opening. Thanks

Net Bait paca craws are amazing I use them as trailers, flipping with a punch weight, texas, carolina, even weightless or shakey head, skys the limits with these things, But my go to jig trailer is the zoom ultravibe speed craw.  For colours I usually stick to my pumpkins and watermelons, but I also like my blues and purples.  every one has a go to bait but these soft plastic craws are definitely mine.

Hey all,  As I gear up for this summer season (if it ever gets warm), I've noticed I have a distinct lack of crayfish plastics in my tackle box. Was wondering what some of your favorite brands and colors were.  I fish in the Paudash lake/Bancroft area if that helps.
Live target in dark,and the Rebel deep craw crank also dark.Mind you these aren't plastics.
Without a doubt, berkley crazylegs chigger craw black and red fleck.

Without a doubt, berkley crazylegs chigger craw black and red fleck. I appreciate it, any other colors work well for you? I haven't had much success with red fleck on my lakes for some reason... the black fleck on another color (ex pumpkin) seems to be killer in other plastics for me  Live target in dark,and the Rebel deep craw crank also dark.Mind you these aren't plastics. I have a couple sitting around in my tackle box... will have to bust them out again this year, they got neglected last season
The rebel crayfish and the cotton Cordell Big-O have been my staples for years.
if your looking for a craw type bait, look no further than NET BAIT!  they are affordable ($5 / pack) and work amazing.
My favorite "craw type" bait isn't a plastic at all, it is a bucktail jig. Color depends on a lot of factors so a selection of colors and weights is esential but I have a few favorites.
OSP Do Live Craw

Only other color i tried was green and red or purple fleck, cant remember??? Where i fish in nw ontario the black/red works amazing. I don't even use any others now. Has to be the crazylegs version though, i bought chigger craws on accident onetime, same color, and my success went way down. I should also add that its not only smallies that love em, walleye do to and 3 of my biggest pike came on these plastics. For pike and bass its usually on a weightless, or lighly weighted wide gap hook, for walleye its on a shakeyhead jig(i like northlands), and small round head jigs for panfish but i cut off the bottom 2/3 of the plastic
Berkley chiggar craws and the osp dolive craws as well. Cheers jeff
OSP Do Live Craw  These are crazy, you'd swear they were real, lol.

2 different types for me when rigged weedless on a worm hook or as a trailer on a jig I have a few that seem to get used up faster than the others  Berkley Chigger Craw Gambler Ugly Otter Strike King Rage Craw  For more clear water finesse (shaky head, jig head) type waters for smallies TUBES!!!!!! and zoom brush hogs
For soft plastics, I bought a bin full of storm craws about 7-8 years ago for a buck or so a pack.  They work great, and I think I'll be handing them down to my kids... LOL
I was checking out done new ones at my friends booth at the spring fishing show they were cool. Check out anglers choice they are also a Canadian made bait here in Ontario.

I was checking out done new ones at my friends booth at the spring fishing show they were cool. Check out anglers choice they are also a Canadian made bait here in Ontario.  A bit lost on the company or how to find the baits... am I missing something here? Supporting local tackle / tackle shops is a big thing when I can do it.
http://www.anglerschoice.ca/
http://www.anglerschoice.ca/ Appreciated, going to seriously check them out.
These are crazy, you'd swear they were real, lol. yup...use them for everything!  Drop shotting with the smaller size is amazing.

yup...use them for everything!  Drop shotting with the smaller size is amazing. Do you have a cheaper place to get them than what's easily searchable on google? The cheapest I could find was $12 for a pack of 7. The way my plastics get beat up, it seems like I'd be running through an awful lot of money that way.
They are expensive anywhere....lol.

Keep your eye on BPS website for the tournament craws at $1 per bag.  It happens and when it does it is well worth it.  I ordered about $100 worth last year.  Texas Red and (surprisingly) the grape purple ones did quite well.
Netbait paca craws are my faves. Tube jigs are the only other craw imitation that I fish once the water warms up.
The rebel crayfish and the cotton Cordell Big-O have been my staples for years. shhhhhhhh.....dont   tell anyone....
I'd have to dig around and pull some out, but if memory serves they come with an internal rattle, and a couple of VMC jig heads.  It was a great deal at the time, but boy do I have crawfish!!!
